Welcome.WelcomeTitle: Volunteer for research to help fight prion disease
Welcome.WelcomeText: Join the Prion Registry, an online registry for people affected by or at risk for prion disease who want to find opportunities to participate in research.
Welcome.Closing: Become a part of this research movement. Let's change the future together.

FirstStep.Title: 1. Register
FirstStep.Text: Click "Join Us" to create an account for yourself or a loved one with prion disease. Once you fill out our easy, online consent form, you will be ready to get started!

SecondStep.Title: 2. Tell us about yourself
SecondStep.Text: You will be asked to fill out a short (less than 10 minutes) questionnaire about yourself and your diagnosis or risk.

ThirdStep.Title: 3. Let's learn together!
ThirdStep.Text: Once your questionnaire is complete, you will be able to view research studies you're eligible to participate in, and contact investigators to enroll. If you let us, we will also contact you about future research opportunities.

Rows.studyName: Assessing Infectivity in Non-CNS Related Tissues in Prion Disease Patients
Rows.description: The goal of this study is to find diagnostic biomarkers and/or infectivity in several tissues outside of the spinal fluid and brain.  Subjects will be asked to give skin swab, hair, blood, and urine samples.
Rows.site: University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Cleveland, Ohio, USA
Rows.eligibilityRequirements: Individuals who are suspected of having a prion disease and have at least one diagnostic study that is suggestive of the condition (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, brain MRI, or electroencephalogram OR those who carry a prion disease causing mutation that are not demonstrating symptoms
Rows.moreInfo: Contact Fran Lissemore, 216-464-6203, fml2@case.edu for more info.

Rows.description: Our goal is to lay the groundwork to test future prion disease therapeutics in people at risk for genetic prion disease -- before they ever experience symptoms. Potential volunteers first have a phone conversation with the study team to answer any questions, confirm eligibility, and collect some baseline information. For eligible individuals who decide to participate, the study involves two visits to Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, MA, with an interval between visits of 8-16 weeks. The study visits would include the following components, performed over 1.5 days: routine physical exam, health questionnaires, lumbar puncture, blood draw, brain imaging scans, cognitive tests. Eligible participants will receive compensation and financial assistance with travel costs. All participation is strictly voluntary.
Rows.eligibilityRequirements:
You may be eligible for this study if any of the following apply to you:
  1. Have a family history of genetic prion disease, including genetic Creutzfeld-Jakob Disease (CJD), fatal familial insomnia (FFI), or Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker syndrome (GSS). Note: you do not need to know your genetic status to participate.
  2. Have received predictive testing indicating that you are at risk for one of the above diseases.
  3. Are from a genetic prion disease family, though not at risk yourself
  4. Wish to volunteer as a control
In addition, participants must be:
- Between the ages of 18-85
- Fluent in English
Rows.moreInfo: See PDF, contact Chase Wennick at 617-643-2351 cwennick@mgh.harvard.edu to enroll

Rows.studyName: Challenging the Huntington Disease Paradigm: Evaluation of Psychosocial Issues in Persons at-risk for Genetic Prion Disease
Rows.description: The purpose of this descriptive study is to examine the psychosocial experience of being at-risk for a genetic prion disease.  Eligible participants for the study will include those who are in one of two groups: 1) those who are at-risk for inheriting a mutation based on family history, but have not undergone predictive testing and 2) those with a mutation confirmed by predictive testing, but who are not yet symptomatic. This anonymous online survey includes questions about psychological adaptation to genetic information and a general mental health assessment, as well as some open-ended questions about experiences of being at-risk and views on the predictive testing process. This study will aim to inform best practices in predictive testing and increase knowledge of the unique psychosocial experience of being at-risk for a genetic prion disease.
Rows.site: Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio, USA
Rows.eligibilityRequirements:
1. Those who are 18 years of age or older.
  2. Those who can read and understand English.
  3. Those who are “at-risk” for a genetic prion disease, meaning that they have a relative affected with the disease.
Rows.moreInfo: Survey here and consent form here.

Rows.studyName: Early Diagnosis of Human Prion Disease
Rows.description: The primary goal of this study is to develop and test methods for differentiating Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) from other diseases and to learn how to diagnose CJD as early as possible. A secondary goal of this study is to learn more about how CJD and other rapid neurological conditions progress by studying these diseases in each patient over time. Because CJD is a rare condition and very rapidly progressive, diagnosis of the disease is often made very late in the illness. If any future treatments for CJD are to be successful, they likely will need to be given to patients as early as possible, before the disease progresses too far. It is therefore important that we learn how to make an accurate diagnosis earlier.
Rows.site: Memory and Aging Center, University of California San Francisco (UCSF), San Francisco, California, USA
Rows.eligibilityRequirements: Inclusion criteria: Patients must be 18 years of age or older. Must fulfill WHO Revised Criteria for CJD, have a family history of familial human prion disease, or have a history of progressive neurologic decline resulting in dementia or significant functional impairment from patient"s baseline over two years or less from symptoms onset. Must have an informant who has frequent contact with the subject and is available to provide information about the subject. Exclusion criteria: Unable to undergo MRI due contraindication to this procedure (e.g., pacemaker, pregnant women). Known HIV positive or immunosuppressed patients.
Rows.moreInfo: See PDF, contact Aili Golubjatnikov at 415-476-2901 Aili.Golubjatnikov@ucsf.edu to enroll

Rows.description: We are recruiting inviduals who are suspected of having a prion disease and have at least one diagnostic study that is suggestive of the condition (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, brain MRI, or electroencephalogram).  We will have approximately monthly telemedicine visits with the patient and a study partner.  The participants will be asked to share their medical and family history as well as to do various assessments instruments (e.g., memory testing, physical examination) by using their own personal computer, phone, or tablet (similar to Skype or Facetime).  The goal of the project is to collect standardized clinical data to help improve diagnosis, surveillance, and knowledge regarding these conditions.
Rows.site: University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Cleveland, Ohio, USA
Rows.eligibilityRequirements: Individuals who are suspected of having a prion disease and have at least one diagnostic study that is suggestive of the condition (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, brain MRI, or electroencephalogram
Rows.moreInfo: Contact CJD Foundation, 800-659-1991, lori@cjdfoundation.org for more info.

Rows.studyName: Therapeutic Antibodies Against Prion Diseases From PRNP Mutation Carriers
Rows.description: Inherited forms of prion diseases usually manifest in higher age so there have to be factors preventing prion propagation in young mutation carriers. Antibodies against the flexible tail of prions have been shown to be protective in mice. The investigators intend to screen mutation carriers and genetically unaffected family members for the presence of prion autoantibodies to develop protective compounds from endogenously occurring autoantibodies.
Rows.site: University of Zurich, Institute of Neuropathology, Zurich, Switzerland
Rows.eligibilityRequirements: Confirmed PRNP mutation carriers (symptomatic+asymptomatic), individuals from families with PRNP mutations without known PRNP status, wild-type PRNP family members from patients with confirmed PRNP mutations
Rows.moreInfo: See PDF, contact Karl Frontzek Karl.Frontzek@usz.ch to enroll

WhatIs.Question: What is prion disease?
WhatIs.Text: Prion disease is a rare neurodegenerative disease caused by a misfolded protein in the brain. It comes in several different subtypes with different names, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), fatal familial insomnia (FFI), and Gertsmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease (GSS).

For.Question: What is this registry for?
For.Text: In order to develop a treatment or cure for prion disease, we need people to participate in research. But prion disease is rare -- it only affects about 1 in 5,000 people in their lifetimes -- so it can be hard to find enough patients to make research possible. This registry allows people affected by, or at risk for, prion disease, to connect with doctors and scientists interested in recruiting for research studies.

Participate.Question: Can I participate in this registry?
Participate.Text: Yes! This registry has a category for everyone. If you're symptomatic with prion disease right now, this registry is for you. If you're healthy but at-risk, this registry is for you. If you aren't at risk but just want to help out by volunteering as a control, this registry is for you too.

Why.Question: Why would I want to participate in this registry?
Why.Text: Prion disease is completely untreatable today -- there is no medicine that can reverse, prevent, or delay the disease. But it won't stay that way forever. We believe that a therapy for prion disease is possible in our lifetimes. Scientists are working hard on making this a reality, but studying cells and mice can only get us so far. In order to develop a treatment, we will need people to participate in research.

DoIHaveTo.Question: Do I have to participate in this registry?
DoIHaveTo.Text: Not at all! This registry is purely voluntary. If you think you'll never want to participate in research, don't sign up. If you don't want to participate in research today, but you might want to in the future, you can always come back later, or you can sign up now but not enroll in any research right away, and just stay tuned.

Text.P1: The Prion Registry has been developed by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard (“
Text.P3: ”) in collaboration with the Prion Registry Consortium. We deeply value your privacy. This Privacy Statement (“
Text.P5: ”) provides important information about how the Prion Registry collects and uses your personal information.
Text.P6Bold: Please make sure you review this Policy before submitting your information to the Prion Registry. If you have any questions about this Policy, please contact us at the addresses listed at the end of this Policy.

Text.P1: The Prion Registry is an online registry, maintained by scientists and prion disease patient advocates at the Broad Institute, for people affected by or at risk for prion disease who want to find opportunities to participate in research. Our ultimate goal is to further the development of life-saving therapies to cure, treat, prevent, or delay prion disease. We created this Registry to make it easier for patients to:

P2Number.2: find research studies to participate in, and

Text.P3: This Registry will also help qualified researchers recruit study participants and gather data. For more information on the Prion Registry, please see PrionRegistry.org. For more information on the Broad Institute, please see https://www.broadinstitute.org/about-us.
Text.P4: Please note that the Registry may link to other websites that are not affiliated with us or the Research Project (“
Text.P6: ”). We may offer those links as a convenience to you but we are not responsible for the privacy practice of those Third-Party Sites. You should make sure you review the privacy policies for those Third-Party Sites before providing them any of your information.

Purpose.Title: 2. What is the purpose and scope of this Policy?

Text.P1: This Policy describes the information we collect from users of the Registry, the purposes for collecting that information, how we use that information, and with whom we share that information.   It applies to users who are patients enrolled in our Research Projects (“
Text.P3: ”), and those users who are not enrolled in any Research Project and are using the Registry for general informational purposes or because they are interested in participating in a future research project (“
Text.P5: ”).  We will refer to all users, including Participant Users and General Users, in this Policy as “

Use.Title: 3. If I use the Registry, am I agreeing to this Policy?
Use.Text: Yes.  However, your use of and contribution of information to the Registry is entirely voluntary and you have certain rights to control use of your information as described below.   If you decide to use the Registry, you are agreeing that we can use your information as described in this Policy.

HowCollect.Title: 4. How do we collect information from you?

Text.P1: We collect information about you in two ways.
Text.P2: First, we collect certain information from you
Text.P3Underline: when you provide it to us directly.
Text.P4: Specifically, we collect information about you when you:
Text.P5Underline: Create a Prion Registry account and profile
Text.P8: by providing us information about you and your experiences with prion disease.  For example, the medical questionnaire in our Registry will ask you a series of questions about your demographics, current prion disease status, willingness to be contacted for trials, past trial participation, zip code and contact information.  Please note that you are not required to answer any question.
Text.P9Underline: Respond to notifications of research opportunities
Text.P10: , surveys and other communications we may send to you.
Text.P13: Second, when you access our Registry, we collect through certain automated technologies that create and log information automatically. For example:
Text.P14: When you visit the Registry website (whether on your computer or on a mobile device), we collect certain information automatically and store it in log files. This information may include IP addresses, the Internet Service Provider, referring/exit pages, date/time stamps, clickstream data, login/logout times, and duration of time spent on the Registry.
Text.P15: We use cookies (small text files sent by your computer each time you visit the Registry that are unique to your account or your browser) for various purposes, including to help us understand how often you use the Registry, where you are accessing the Registry from and events that happen on the Registry. We use a mix of automated tools and services, such as Google Analytics and MixPanel, to evaluate and improve our Registry.   We may also use third-party tracking technologies to detect malicious code or attacks on our Registry.  These entities may use cookies and other tracking technologies to perform their services.

WhatCollect.Title: 5. What kind of information do we collect?

Text.P2: : Information that alone or in combination with other information may be used to readily identify, contact, or locate you.  For example, your name, zip code, trial participation status and email address, are personal information you may provide to us through your use of the Registry. If you provide someone else's personal information (for example, you submit information to the registry on someone else’s behalf of or provide details of family medical history that may identify a family member) you should make them aware, to the extent that their soundness of mind allows, that you have provided the information to us.  We will only use such personal information in accordance with this privacy policy and applicable law.
Text.P4: . The medical questionnaire in the Registry will ask you for information about your experience with prion disease and willingness to participate in research.
Text.P6: : Information related to your usage of the Registry, including the pages you view, the links you click, and the length of time you visit our Registry.
Text.P8: : Information that relates to a particular computer, mobile device, or other device (e.g. iPad) that you use to access the Registry. Device information includes your IP address (which is a number assigned by an internet service provider to the computer you use to access the Internet), a device ID (which is a number assigned to a mobile phone by the device manufacturer), or the type of operating system or web browser used to access the Registry.

Cookies.Title: 6. Do we use cookies and other tracking technologies?

Text.P1: Yes.  We use cookies for various purposes, such as to make it easier for you to navigate our Registry, to enable a faster log-in process or to better understand user interactions with the Registry.  There are two types of cookies: session and persistent cookies.
Text.P3: .  Session cookies exist only during a session.  They disappear from your computer or device when you close your browser or turn off your computer or device.  We use Session Cookies to allow our systems to uniquely identify you during a session or while you are logged in to the Registry.  This allows us to process your communications and requests and verify your identity after you have logged in and as you move through our Registry, and to optimize your experience in using the Registry.
Text.P5: .  Persistent Cookies remain on your computer or device after you have closed your browser or the Registry or turned off your computer or mobile device.  We use persistent cookies to track aggregate and statistical information about user activity on our Registry (see “Tracking Technologies” below).
Text.P7: You may opt-out of non-essential cookies by selecting “Reject Cookies” or by clicking on “Manage Preferences” in the prompt asking whether you accept the use of cookies. Non-essential cookies are those that allow us to monitor site usage and improve the site, such as Google Analytics. Other cookies, however, are essential to the website’s functionality, including those cookies that allow you to stay logged into the site while you use it. The only way to opt out of these essential cookies is to not join the site.
Text.P8: You may also view and manage your cookie preferences by clicking on the button below.
Text.P10: We use automated devices, applications, and analytic tools such as Google Analytics, to evaluate usage of our Registry and improve our user experience and performance.  We may also use third-party tracking technologies, such as tCell, to detect malicious code or attacks on our Registry.  These entities may use cookies and other tracking technologies to perform their services.  We do not share your personal information with these third parties.
Text.P12: We respond to browser-level Do Not Track (“
Text.P14: ”) signals by disabling optional tracking technologies such as Google Analytics, however, we do not disable tracking that is essential to the website’s functionality, such as cookies that allow you to stay logged in. For information about DNT, visit www.allaboutdnt.org.

HowUse.Title: 6. How do we use your information?

Text.P1: We use your data for the following purposes only:
Text.P3: We use the information you provide about yourself, your medical condition, and experiences to identify opportunities for you to participate in research. If you agree, you may choose to be contacted about future research studies and/or clinical trials in which you may be eligible to participate. You may also choose not to receive these invitations or decline to participate in future studies. Please note that the research studies with whom we partner only receive aggregate, de-identified data from our participants unless you enter into a separate research consent with them. This aggregate data does not identify you personally.
Text.P4BoldUnderline: Provide the Registry and Communicate with You.
Text.P5: We, together with our collaborators, vendors, and service providers, use your information to operate the Registry, respond to your inquiries, notify you of research opportunities, ask you to periodically update your profile and health status, and for other communication purposes.
Text.P7: We will use the information you provide to generate de-identified, aggregate descriptive statistics, such as the number of people interested in participating in prion disease research in a given geographic area. These statistics may be used to perform research, such as characterizing the prevalence of prion disease, or to promote prion disease research, for example, by securing funding or collaborations. As part of this work, we may use the information you provide to verify the accuracy of the Registry data, develop scientific publications, and answer questions from IRBs, IECs or government or regulatory agencies.
Text.P9: We use your information to tailor the content and information that we may send or display to you, to offer location customization, and personalized help and instructions, and to otherwise personalize your experiences while you are using the Registry.
Text.P11: We use your information to ensure our Registry is working as intended, to better understand how users access and use our Registry, both on an aggregated and individualized basis, to understand the features that our Registry find valuable, make improvements to our Registry, to develop new features and applications, and for other research and analytical purposes.

ShareWith.Title: 7. With whom do we share your information?

Text.P1: The Prion Registry does not sell or share your information for marketing purposes, but we may share your information in the following ways:
Text.P3: After removing your name and any other readily identifiable information, Registry staff may share statistics regarding de-identified data with researchers or organizations interested in launching research studies. For example, staff may provide information regarding the number of individuals in the registry who qualify for a potential research study, based on age, genetic mutation status, location, and/or other information. This information could be used to help design a study or secure funding or collaboration commitments. Qualified researchers who have received approval from an ethics committee will also be able to post studies for which you will be notified of your eligibility. An ethics committee is a group that independently reviews and watches over all research studies involving people. The board follows local laws and codes of ethics to make sure that the rights and welfare of people taking part in research studies are protected.
Text.P4Bold: It will then be your choice whether to contact these researchers and share your identity in order to enroll in their studies; researchers will not be able to directly view your contact information in the registry.
Text.P6: We use various third-party vendors and service providers that assist us in providing the Registry.  For example, we may use third-party vendors to store and authenticate account credentials, store and analyze system logs, send email communications, and for hosting and storing information collected through our Registry.  We may need to share your information with these vendors and service providers to enable them to provide these services to us.  These service providers and vendors are required to only use your information to provide their services to us and in a manner consistent with this Policy.
Text.P8: We may be required, by law, to disclose your personal information to third parties, such as in the following situations:
Text.P9: In response to a request by law enforcement;
Text.P10: In response to legal process, such as a subpoena, a request for discovery in a civil proceeding, or in response to a court order.
Text.P11: We may also access, preserve, and disclose your personal information to enforce the terms of use for the Registry and protect your, our, or others’ rights, property, or safety.
Text.P13: Broad Institute may be involved in a business transaction where its ownership or assets are transferred or sold to another legal entity.  This can happen in a merger with another legal entity, an acquisition by another legal entity, a corporate reorganization, or a legal proceeding (e.g. bankruptcy or receivership), where a trustee or other takes over control of the entity.  In each of these situations, your information may be transferred as part of such a transaction as permitted by law and/or contract. The successor in interest will continue to be bound by the terms of this Policy.
Text.P15: We may ask you from time to time to give us permission to share your information with other third parties not described in this section.  In each case, we will describe that third party and the purpose for sharing your information.
Text.P17: We may share aggregate or de-identified information about users and their use of the Registry with third parties and publicly for reporting, funding applications, research, or similar purposes.  This information will not identify you personally.

Text.P1: The Registry may link to other websites that are not affiliated with us (“
Text.P3: ”).  We may offer those links as a convenience to you but we are not responsible for the privacy practice of those Third-Party Sites.  [For example, we use Google Cloud to host the Registry and Auth0 as an authentication system to provide access to the Registry.] Other sites may have different privacy practices. You should make sure you review the privacy policies of those Third-Party Sites before providing any of your information to them.

OtherUsers.Title: 9. Can other users see my information?
OtherUsers.Text: Users will not be able to post content that is visible to any other users of the Registry.  Your information will only be made available to us, our research partners, our service providers and vendors, and the other third parties listed in Section 7.

InformationRights.Title: 10. What rights do I have with respect to my information?

Text.P1: Registered users can request to update, receive a copy of, or delete information submitted to the Registry by clicking on the button below:
Text.P2: We will respond to any user request as soon as we reasonably can, and within the time and in the manner required by law.   We may request additional information from you to verify the request.  We may not be able to accommodate all requests; for example, we may be unable to accommodate a deletion request if we are required to maintain information under law or a legal obligation or if information is used as part of a published study.

Security.Title: 11. What kind of security does the Registry use to protect my information?

Text.P1: We use reasonable security to protect the information we collect from users. These safeguards encompass administrative, technical, and physical procedures and controls, including:
Text.P2: encryption of information in transit and at rest on servers;
Text.P8: However, we cannot guarantee the security of information we collect or any transmission of information over the Internet.  For this reason, you should make sure that you keep your profile account on the Registry confidential, including any user identification or password.  You should also notify us immediately if there has been any unauthorized use of your account.

Children.Title: 12. Do you collect personal information from children?
Children.Text: The Registry is not designed or intended for use by individuals under the legal age of majority in their location of residence, and we do not knowingly collect information from such individuals. If we become aware that we have information for minors, we will promptly delete it. Anyone who believes that we may have such information from individuals under the legal age of majority should contact us at the addresses provided below.

Country.Title: 13. Is there any transfer of personal information from one country to another?
Country.Text: We store and process the information you provide on servers in the United States.  If you are a user of the Registry, you agree to the transfer of your information to the United States and acknowledge that the laws in the United States may offer less protection to your information than the laws where you live.

Contact.Title: 14. Whom do I contact if I have a question or request?

Text.P1: You may contact us at the addresses below if you have any questions or complaints about information practices or this Policy:
Text.P5: The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

Update.Title: 15. Will you update or change this Policy?

Text.P1: We may modify this Policy from time to time, and you can see when the last update was by looking at the “Last Updated” date at the top of this page. If you object to any changes, you may stop accessing the Registry. Your continued use of the Registry after we post an updated Policy means that you acknowledge the updated Policy following the date it takes effect.
Text.P2: As a general practice, we will not use your personal information for uses or purposes that are significantly different from those described in this Policy.  However, from time to time, we may need to use your information for uses not previously disclosed in this Policy.  If this should happen, we will use reasonable efforts to notify you and obtain your consent to such new uses as required by law.

EU.Title: 16. Notice to Residents of the European Union

Text.P1: This section outlines certain additional information that we are obligated to provide to data subjects of the European Union pursuant to the European Union General Data Protection Regulation 2016/679 and its amendments (“
Text.P3: ”).  We act as a data controller under the GDPR for the personal data that we collect from users of the Registry.  For such personal data, we rely on the following legal bases for processing such information:
Text.P5: We may use your personal data for our legitimate interests provided that our legitimate interests are not outweighed by any prejudice or harm to your interests, rights and freedoms, including:
Text.P6: improving our products and services and the content on Registry (for example to manage the Registry, improve the Registry, and better tailor the features, performance and support of the Registry);
Text.P8: promoting the safety and security of the Registry;
Text.P9: fulfilling your requests and communicating with you when you contact us; and
Text.P12: In some cases, you will give us consent to use your personal data for a specific purpose.  For example, we will rely on your consent to use technical information such as cookie data and health information to identify relevant research studies.
Text.P14: We may be required to process your personal data to comply with our legal obligations.
Text.P16: We retain personal information about you for the time necessary to accomplish the purpose for which such information was collected, usually for any period thereafter as legally required or permitted by applicable law.  Our retention policies reflect applicable statute of limitation periods and legal requirements.
Text.P18: Data subjects of the European Union have the following rights:
Text.P20: You have the right to be informed about the collection and use of your personal data.
Text.P22: You have the right to request copies of your personal data.
Text.P24: You have the right to request that we correct any information you believe is inaccurate. You also have the right to request that we complete information that you believe is incomplete.
Text.P26: You have the right to request that we erase your personal data, under certain conditions.
Text.P28: You have the right to request that we erase your personal data, under certain conditions.
Text.P29Bold: The right to object to processing -
Text.P30: You have the right to object to our processing of your personal data, under certain circumstances.
Text.P32: You have the right to request that we transfer the data that we have collected to another organization, or directly to you, under certain conditions.
Text.P33: If you believe our processing of your personal data violates data protection laws, you have a legal right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority responsible for data protection.  You may do so in the EU member state of your habitual residence, your place of work or the place of the alleged violation.
Text.P35: EU data subjects can submit requests by clicking on the “Data Request” button in section 10 above.  We will respond to all such requests within 30 days of our receipt of all information required for us to act on a request, unless there are extenuating circumstances or complex / multiple requests, in which event we may take up to 90 days to respond.  We will inform you if we expect our response to take longer than 30 days.  Please note, however, that certain personal data may be exempt from such rights pursuant to applicable data protection laws.  In addition, we will not respond to any request unless we are able to appropriately verify the requester’s identity. In addition, if we consider that a request is manifestly unfounded or excessive, we may either request a reasonable fee to deal with the request or refuse to deal with the request.
